utterances: Meg Smith manages the BookSense list.
It's almost like the original social networking, of the best-seller list because you see what other people have read and what other people have bought.
And as a reader and as a browser, you think, huh, well, that's been selling, then maybe it's something I would like as well.
Smith says independent booksellers also play a role in driving books on the best-seller list that would not have gotten there otherwise.
One example she cites is ""Water for Elephants,"" a best-seller that was so successful that Sara Gruen, a previously unknown author, now has a multimillion dollar deal for her next two books.
Smith says it was buzz among independent booksellers that gave that book its initial momentum.
And it really changed the plans of the publisher and how many books, ultimately, they went to print on.
And that buzz that began with the independent bookstores, yes, it did translate very concretely to sales and then, ultimately, to the book being taken up very large in the chains.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""SOUL FOOD"")
I want to make sure everybody understands we're sitting here saying we dodged a bullet.
Compared to Ivan, we dodged a bullet.
We still had a hurricane.
The Escambia County Sheriffs Department in Pensacola let relatives of department employees use the building as a storm shelter.
Yesterday evening, just a few hours after Dennis made landfall, people streamed from the shelter into the parking lot carrying their sleeping bags and pillows.
An outdoor generator kept power going inside.
(Soundbite of generator)
Helen White(ph) rode out the storm with her grandkids at the sheriffs department.
Last year, Hurricane Ivan crumbled her mobile home.
I said after Ivan I would never stay in town for the next one, but I'm here still.
She bought a new home after Ivan.
Dennis spared it.
I'm about to go back home, and all I have now is no electricity.
I still have my house, but I have no electricity.
But that'll be fine.
That'll be on in a few days, if not tomorrow.
With sustained winds of 120 miles an hour, Dennis did cause damage.
Across the sheriffs department parking lot, the wind ripped some metal sheeting off of the walls of a gas station.
One piece dangled like a loose tooth as the last gust of the storm passed through.
(Soundbite of metal sheeting)
Grover Barns(ph) is the sheriffs department mechanic who rode out the storm with a group of men in a nearby garage.
When them garage doors were moving in and out as the gusts were coming, it looked like they were going to come in the building with us.
We were somewhat apprehensive.
As a matter of fact, we was scared.
As Barns talks, Sheriffs Department Sergeant Ted Roy pulls his car into the garage to get a tire changed.
(Soundbite of electric tool)
He's just come back from Pensacola Beach which is still closed to the public.
He says the scale of emergency response to this hurricane does not even compare with that of Ivan.
For example, the first priority after Ivan was search and rescue.
We had over 700 or 900 calls--I can't remember which one it was--waiting to be answered and a lot of them were, `Come save me.
There's water in my house.
Please help me,' when we had to say, `We can't, we can't make it yet.
This time, we didn't have any of those calls waiting.
Roy says the main priority this time is cleanup.
Power crews and dump trucks are hitting the road this morning.
Ari Shapiro, NPR News.
In Austin, Texas, the annual South by Southwest Music Festival is in full swing.
More than a thousand acts will take to the stage.
At South by Southwest, few people are busier than Andy Langer.
He's a local Austin DJ, and he's built a national reputation with his ear for talent.
NPR's Neda Ulaby is at South by Southwest.
She spent a day with Andy Langer and some people who look to him for the latest buzz about the hottest new musicians.
Andy Langer staunchly denies having much of a musical influence on the national music scene.
But some think his taste is impeccable.
I think people recognize Andy as the go-to guy in Texas.
That's Lyle Lovett.
He's on tour.
He phoned in from the road.
If I'm going to come to town for the weekend to Austin, we'll call Andy and say, who's in town?
Who's playing?
What's going on?
In Austin right now, the answer would be 1,300 bands playing literally 24 hours a day at clubs, bars, street corners and hotel lobbies.
(Soundbite of music)
During South by Southwest, Andy Langer hosts a show first thing every morning, at 7 AM in the plush Four Seasons Hotel lobby.
There he introduces up-and-coming bands to the kind of people who stay at the Four Seasons.
(Soundbite of music)
(Singing) Oh, baby, you're for me.
Even so early, it's standing room only.
But that's not unusual for Austin.
Where your Monday or Tuesday night audience looks like a Friday or Saturday audience in any other city.
You know, people have made it their priority to go see live music on a regular basis.
Even for Austin, this week is extreme.
It's like Austin on steroids.
This is a small town with a big music community.
You know, they call it the little town with the big guest list.
Andy Langer believes the acts most likely to break out of South by Southwest this year are international.
He mentions Amy Winehouse, the young British singer with a much-publicized appetite for booze, and a singer from Scotland barely out of his teens.
(Soundbite of music)
(Singing) Hey, hey.
It's still early in young Paolo Nutini's career.
He's a genuine, singular talent.
I mean, he sings a little different than everyone.
He writes a little different than everyone.
(Singing) You said you'd marry me if I was 23.
But I'm one night you can see if I'm only 18.
Tell me who made these rules...
I expect there's going to be a giant, James Blunt kind of backlash against him later on.
People are going to think he's a little too precious, a little too quaint.
But I think people are going to like Paolo Nutini in the kind of numbers that allow for backlash.
It's not just newbies creating buzz at South by Southwest.
In the sort of moment the festival is known for, The Who's Pete Townshend joined Ian McLagan of The Faces in a tribute to musician Ronnie Lane.
(Soundbite of music)
Hey Pete, sing one for Ronnie, would you?
(Soundbite of music)
(Singing) She learned me, life is sweet, God is good.
Well, the appropriately named Matthew Brightman, of Lyndhurst, Ohio, writes this: thank you for telling me what those two immensely bright objects are in the sky.
Every night, I walk my dog wondering what they are and why I haven't noticed them previously.
Now, despite my laziness to find out on my own, ALL THINGS CONSIDERED has done the legwork for me.
But not all the legwork, Michael Hall of Arlington, Virginia, writes this: Our children are very excited.
Now, can you do something about the clouds?
Well, if it's too cloudy for stargazing, you can have your kids read the next book for NPR's Backseat Book Club.
The book is ""The Mysterious Benedict Society."" Then send their questions to Backseat Book Club at NPR.org.
And as always, you can send us letters at NPR.org by clicking on Contact Us.
After 168 years of being read aloud at British breakfast tables, the News of the World published its final edition today.
Media tycoon Rupert Murdoch shut down the tabloid to try and contain a growing phone tapping scandal.
The paper's accused of illegally hacking into the cell phones of thousands of sports stars and newsmakers, including a young murder victim.
